The photothermal catalytic reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS) can convert CO2 into other high-value-added chemical resources under mild conditions. However, the design and development of high-performance catalysts is a major challenge. In this work, different proportions of CuCe bimetallic catalysts were synthesized using the sol-gel method and applied to RWGS. Under the visible light heat catalytic condition at 450 ℃, the CO yield can be increased by about 20 % compared to thermal catalysis, which is better than most metal-based catalysts reported in the literature. Moreover, the catalyst exhibited good stability and reusability, with the primary factor affecting the stability of the CuCe catalyst being the growth of Cu nanoparticles. The characterization shows that at Cu/Ce=1, the separation efficiency of electron-hole separation is the highest, and the hot electrons generated by the LSPR effect of Cu can be effectively separated and transferred, producing more oxygen vacancies and suitable alkaline sites, so it has the best photothermal catalytic performance. Furthermore, the catalyst is dominated by the formate pathway under light conditions, and this work provides a new RWGS strategy. Graphical Abstract A series of CuCe catalysts with different ratios were prepared and applied to photothermal catalytic RWGS. The importance of oxygen vacancy in photothermal catalysis was explained, and the different catalytic cycle paths under light and dark conditions were speculated, which provided a new reaction strategy for RWGS. Keywords CO2 reduction Oxygen vacancy Photothermal catalyst CeO2 Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The rapid increase in atmospheric concentrations of CO2, the main greenhouse gas (GHS), has led to global warming and major environmental problems [1]. CO2 is a cheap, non-toxic and abundant C1 raw material. Therefore, large-scale use of CO2 to produce other useful chemicals could prove to be a viable way to reduce global GHS emissions [2]. In the last decade, photocatalytic CO2 reduction has received considerable attention as a potential “green” technology for reducing CO2 emissions in the production of fuels (CH4, CH3OH) and valuable commodity chemicals (CO, HCOOH) [3]. However, for most photocatalysts developed so far for CO2 reduction, low product selectivity and low activity are the most important limiting factors for their application [4]. The Cu/ZnO catalyst prepared by He et al. [5] gave a CO yield of 300 μmol·g−1·h−1 under photothermal conditions by simple precipitation, which was much higher than the CO yield of pure photocatalysis and pure thermal catalysis under the same conditions, suggesting that Photothermal co-catalysis showed unique advantages in catalyzing CO2 reduction and was a promising catalytic method. Compared to photocatalytic CO2 reduction, photothermal techniques offer much higher catalytic yields for C1 compounds (CO or CH4) under most conditions [6]. Therefore, there is an urgent need to develop novel photothermal catalysts that enable the selective reduction of CO2 to specific products [7]. CeO2 is a common lanthanide rare earth metal oxide with face-centered cubic (FCC) fluorite structure and has properties that can be exploited to improve catalytic performance [8], especially its tunable electronic structure and excellent photocatalytic performance have attracted great attention. Lai et al. [9] characterized iron-doped porous CeO2 prepared by combustion method and found that the inclusion of Fe reduced the conduction band edge of CeO2, significantly improved the light absorption performance, and the CO yield of PFeCe samples was nine times that of CeO2. Li et al. [10] confirmed through the preparation of Ce1-xZrxO2 that doping of Zr effectively regulates the oxygen vacancy in CeO2 and influences the behavior of photogenerated charge carrier through the oxygen vacancy, thereby improving the photocatalytic activity. By doping with transition metals, the CeO2 semiconductor not only receives a higher concentration of photogenerated charge carriers, but also expands its optical absorption range, which can improve its optical properties [11]. In recent years, metals with photocatalytic activity have been discovered, such as Zr [10], Fe [9], Ni [12], Co [13], Ti [14], Cu [15], etc. have been applied in the field of photocatalysis for CO2 reduction, and some have shown obvious advantages in catalyzing RWGS. Among them, Cu has been extensively studied because it produces less CH4 as a byproduct and has high selectivity for CO [15]. Cai et al. [16] found that CuCe co-doping can produce doping energy levels at which Cu-Ce co-doping has little effect on the band gap width, but significantly improves the lifetime of the photogenerated carriers and expands the range of light absorption. Yang et al. [17] synthesized CuCeO2 samples using the hydrothermal immersion method, and the CO production by photothermal catalysis was 30 % higher than that by thermal catalysis. A series of in situ techniques proved that Cu nanoparticles on the surface of the sample created a local surface plasmon resonance (LSPR) effect, which accelerated the formation of oxygen vacancies. The oxygen vacancy is involved in the adsorption and activation of CO2 in the form of double teeth (HCOO*), which affects the spill over of H2 from the Cu to CeO2 surface. Ponnar et al. [18] studied the optical properties and crystal structure of Cu-Ce prepared by the microwave radiation method and proved that Ce ions can replace Cu ions and thus change the optical properties of CuO nanoparticles, thereby making the Cu-Ce-Catalyst is more prone to absorbing low-wavelength light. The morphology of Ce metal doping can optimize the aggregation of CuO. These studies show that photothermal catalysis of RWGS with CuCe has become a promising method for converting CO2 to CO, but there are still some problems such as low conversion efficiency and unclear mechanism of photothermal collaborative catalysis. Cu-Ce catalysts prepared by the impregnation method [19], the combustion method [2] and the template method [20] are affected by long preparation times, many influencing factors and uneven catalyst doping and dispersion, etc. While the sol-gel preparation method is expected to obtain catalysts with smaller catalyst particles and more uniform dispersion and better improve the lattice oxygen activity. Therefore, in this work, we prepared CuCe bimetallic catalysts with different proportions by sol-gel method and applied them to photothermal catalysis of RWGS. The effect of Cu/Ce ratio on photothermal catalytic performance was studied by some characterization methods, indicating the importance of oxygen vacancy for photothermal catalysis of CuCe bimetallic catalysts, and exploring the reaction path of catalysts in photothermal catalysis. Finally, a promising catalyst for photothermal catalytic conversion was obtained. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation CuCe bimetallic oxide catalysts with different Cu:Ce atomic ratios of 1: 3, 1: 1, and 3: 1 were prepared by the sol-gel method. According to the molar ratio, Cu(NO3)2·3H2O, Ce(NO3)3·6H2O and citric acid are named separately, and the molar ratio of citric acid and all metal atoms is 1: 1. Then they were added into 10 mL of distilled water and stirred evenly. At this point, the pH of the mixed solution is about 2. The resulting mixed solution was first stirred in a water bath at 65 ℃ until it gelled then dried overnight in a constant temperature oven at 120 ℃. The resulting sample was calcined in a tube furnace at 500 ℃ for three hours in an air atmosphere to obtain CuCe bimetallic oxide catalysts named 1Cu3Ce, 1Cu1Ce and 3Cu1Ce, respectively. Pure CeO2 is produced directly by mixing a certain amount of Ce(NO3)3·6H2O with citric acid according to the above method and is named CeO2. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The X-ray diffraction spectra (XRD) of samples were measured by DX-2700BH X-ray diffractometer. The specific surface area and pore distribution were determined by physical adsorption desorption with BSD-PM2 high performance specific surface area and micropore analyzer. The specific surface area and pore volume of the sample were calculated by Bruner-Emmett-Teller (BET) and Barrett-Joyner Halenda (BJH) methods. Thermo Fisher Scientific Talos F200S was used to observe the surface morphology of the catalyst, and Super-x spectrometer was used to perform EDS-Mapping. Temperature programmed reduction of hydrogen (H2-TPR) was performed on the ASAP-2920 instrument. Thermo Scientific™ K-Alpha™ energy spectrometer was used to analyze the valence state of the reduced catalyst and its surrounding electronic environment, in which the experimental parameter was Cu Kα (power 250 W, voltage 14 kV) as the ray source. The combination of elements can be calibrated with a C1s peak (284.8 eV). Raman spectroscopy was performed on the reduced samples at Renishaw using a microscope Raman spectrometer equipped with a 50X objective and the Leica microscopy system. PE Avio 200 inductively coupled plasma atomic emission spectroscopy (ICP-AES) was used to quantitatively analyze the element content in the catalyst. CO2-TPD was tested from 30℃ to 800℃ using ASAP-2920 device. The reduced catalyst was characterized by solid diffuse reflection (UV–vis) using UV 3600I plus. Photoluminescence analysis (PL) was performed by Hitachi F-7000 molecular fluorometer. Electrochemical impedance test was performed at the electrochemical workstation. Thermo Scientific NICOLET iS50 FT-IR spectrometer was used to monitor the reaction process by injecting reaction gas into the reduced sample. The thermal imaging test was performed with HIKMICRO's H16 device, and the images were taken after 10 s of irradiation with a 300 W all-band xenon lamp source. 5 µL of the mixture was removed and coated on the electrode surface after the 5.000 mg sample was precisely weighed and distributed in 2 mL DMF. Next, 4 µL of Nafion 117 perfluorinated resin was added. By adding 0.1 mol/L KCl+5 mmol/L potassium ferricyanide (potassium ferricyanide) to the mixed solution, the electrochemical impedance was ascertained. The theoretical electrochemical impedance value is determined by measuring the arc diameter in the high frequency region. The temperature was heated to 400 ℃ at a heating rate of 10 ℃·min−1, 20 % H2 was injected for reduction for 30 min, and then He gas was injected for purging for 15 min. At 400 ℃, 10 mL·min−1 was injected into the reaction tank according to the gas ratio of CO2/H2/N2=15/60/25, and infrared scanning was performed. The scanning times were 32 times. After He gas purging for 15 min, the light was turned on and the reaction gas was injected according to the above steps for the experiment, and then the temperature was successively lowered to 350 ℃, 300 ℃ and 250 ℃ for scanning, respectively. 100 mg of the sample was weighed and its Cu dispersion was tested using the N2O titration method. The sample was reduced for 1 h in a 10 % H2/N2 mixture (30 mL·min−1) at 350℃, and the amount of H2 consumed during reduction was recorded as X. The catalyst bed was then purged with He and cooled to 50℃. At 50℃, the sample was oxidized for 1 h in a 20 % N2O/N2 mixture (30 mL·min−1) to ensure complete oxidation of metallic Cu. The sample was then flushed with N2 for 0.5 h to remove N2O and cooled to room temperature. The sample was subjected to a second reduction under the same conditions, and the hydrogen consumption in the second TPR was recorded as Y. Cu dispersion was calculated using the following formula: Dispersion of Cu : D C u = 2 Y X × 100 % 2.3 Evaluation of catalytic performance The CO2 reduction reaction was carried out in a fixed-bed quartz tube reactor. Before the reaction, 20 mg of catalyst was added to the quartz tube. The heating rate is set at 10 ℃·min−1 and the hydrogen flow rate is set at 20 mL min−1. The pre-reduction was carried out at 400 ℃ for 30 min. After the prereduction was completed, N2 was injected for purging and the temperature was increased to 450 ℃. Then Reactive gas was injected into the reactor in the ratio of H2: CO2: Ar=6: 1.5: 2.5. The total gas flow rate was 10 mL min−1. The light source of the Xe lamp was turned on and adjusted to the intensity of the light source 20 A. (Beijing Perfectlight Technology Co.,Ltd. PLS-SXE300+，Electric power 300 W) The reaction was carried out in the temperature range of 200–450 ℃ and the resulting components were detected using the thermal conductivity detector (TCD) SP7890 Plus gas chromatography (GC). The conversion rate of CO2 and selectivity of CO to catalyst are calculated by the following formula: CO 2 Conversion : X CO 2 = F CO 2 , inlet − F CO 2 , outlet F CO 2 , inlet × 100 % CO Selectivity : S CO = F CO , outlet F CO , outlet + F CH 4 , outlet × 100 % 3 Results and discussion The XRD patterns of CuCe and CeO2 catalysts after calcination are shown in Fig. 1. For pure CeO2, eight typical peaks of 2θ at 28.55°, 33.08°, 47.48°, 56.34°, 59.09°, 69.42°, 76.70° and 79.08° are attributed to the CeO2 phase of cerianite (PDF#43-1002) [19]. With the increase of Cu content, an obvious CuO characteristic peak of tenorite can be observed (PDF#48-1548), among which 1Cu3Ce does not have the characteristic peak of black copper CuO, which may be due to the low Cu content and uniform distribution in the catalyst [21]。When comparing the diffraction peaks of the CeO2(111) crystal face and the CuO(11−1) crystal face of the three catalysts with the standard PDF card ( Table 1), it is found that the diffraction peaks of CeO2(111) and CuO(11−1) in the three CuCe catalysts all move to a higher 2θ value, representing the formation of the solid solution phase CuxCe1-xO2-y [22]. The formation of the solid solution phase is attributed to the strong interaction between CuO and CeO2 in the CuCe mixed oxide catalyst, which weakens the Ce-O and Cu-O bonds, facilitating the formation of oxygen vacancies. Compared with the diffraction peak of CeO2, it can be seen that the intensity of the diffraction peak decreases after the addition of Cu, indicating that the addition of Cu reduces the crystallinity of CeO2, which contributes to the solid solution in the form of Cu-O-Ce interface [22]. Furthermore, these oxygen vacancies created by solid solutions are not limited to a single oxygen site but also extend to other oxygen sites in the environment [23]. The formation of a large number of oxygen vacancies favors the adsorption and activation of reactant molecules and promotes the hydrogenation-reduction reaction of CO2. According to the Bragg equation, the grain size of the CeO2(111) crystal plane is 1Cu3Ce>3Cu1Ce>1Cu1Ce from high to low, and the grain size of the CuO(11−1) crystal plane of 1Cu1Ce and 3Cu1Ce is 16.09 nm and 14.90 nm, respectively. Cu dispersion in 1Cu1Ce and 3Cu1Ce was tested using N2O titration (Table S1). It was observed that Cu dispersion in 3Cu1Ce is higher than in 1Cu1Ce, which is the main reason for the smaller Cu particle size in 3Cu1Ce compared to 1Cu1Ce. Since 1Cu1Ce has the smallest CeO2 and larger CuO grains compared to 3Cu1Ce-CeO2 species, it is easier to penetrate into the CuO lattice, which further confirms the formation of the CuxCe1-xO2-y solid solution phase. Comparing the calcined catalyst with the catalyst reduced before the reaction for 1Cu1Ce catalyst (Fig. 12), it can be seen that there is no obvious characteristic peak of tenorite CuO (PDF#48–1548) in the reduced catalyst, indicating that most Cu species in the catalyst are reduced to Cu0. This will be further validated in the characterization of H2-TPR and XPS. Fig. 2 shows the N2 adsorption-desorption isotherms of CuCe and CeO2. It can be seen from the figure that the isotherms of CuCe catalysts are typical type Ⅳ isotherms and have a type H3 hysteresis loop, indicating that the catalyst has a mesoporous structure. Combined with the pore structure data in Table 1, the existence of a mesoporous structure is also confirmed. After Cu doping, the specific surface area is 1Cu1Ce>1Cu3Ce>3Cu1Ce in the order from large to small. For 1Cu1Ce and 1Cu3Ce, at low Cu content, the surface area occupied by Cu nanoparticles affects the specific surface area of the catalyst, and the pore size also changes [19]. In addition, according to the grain size of the CuO(11−1) crystal surface of 3Cu1Ce (14.90 nm), the pore distribution in the mesopore region can be obviously observed in the pore size distribution diagram (Fig. S1), indicating that large CuO particles collect in 3Cu1Ce attaches to the pore wall and then the specific surface area decreases [19]. A better pore structure and surface promote the mass transfer process of the catalyst. As shown in the TEM images in Figs. S2-S5, all Cu-Ce bimetallic catalysts exhibit irregular hollow block structures. By observing the EDS-elemental analysis of the energy spectrum scan (Fig. S6), three elements Cu, Ce and O can be found. The distribution of Ce and O in the energy spectrum is more uniform, but the distribution of Cu on the surface is more concentrated. Comparing the bulk phase element content test results of ICP-AES in Table 2, the EDS characterization results were found to be consistent with those from ICP-AES, confirming the successful synthesis of the catalyst。In addition, the oxygen species content on the surface of 1Cu1Ce is the highest, followed by 1Cu3Ce and 3Cu1Ce, indicating that the 1Cu1Ce can generate the most oxygen vacancies. By looking at the HRTEM diagram and calculating the crystal face distance ( Fig. 3), it can be clearly seen that the catalyst surface has relatively small crystal face distances of 0.31 nm and 0.30 nm, which include the crystal face distance close to 0.31 nm to CeO2-crystal surface (111). The facet spacing near 0.30 nm is mainly attributed to the (11−1) facet of CuO, and this similar facet spacing promotes the formation of solid solutions, which supports the results of XRD characterization. To investigate the reduction performance of the catalyst, the calcined catalyst was characterized using H2-TPR. The results are shown in Fig. 4. It can be seen that CeO2 has two weak reduction peaks, around 500 ℃ and above 700 ℃, which is due to the reduction of a small amount of adsorbed oxygen and bulk oxygen species. The three CuCe catalysts also have two obvious reduction peaks, and the reduction peak at low temperature is mainly attributed to the reduction of dispersed CuO and CeO2 at the CuO-CeO2 interface [24]. The other reduction peak is mainly attributed to the reduction of the remaining CuO and a small amount of CeO2 in the bulk phase [24]. It was found that the reduction peak shifted to low temperatures after Cu incorporation, indicating that Cu incorporation promotes the reduction of oxygen species on the catalyst surface. In addition, the reduction peaks of the three CuCe catalysts all start at 100 ℃ and end before 300 ℃, which is lower than the reduction temperature of CuO (300 ℃) [25], indicating that the reduction capacity of CuO is effectively improved with the incorporation of Ce, and the degree of reduction is increased with the increase of the Ce content. The reduction temperature of CeO2 is much higher than 400 ℃, which confirms the formation of a solid solution phase between Cu and Ce. When comparing the reduction peak area, it was found that the reduction peak area of CeO2 was much smaller than that of the three CuCe catalysts, indicating that the addition of Cu increased the content of reducible oxygen species on the catalyst surface. Combined with EDS mapping characterization analysis, although CeO2 has the most oxygen species, the low content of reducible oxygen species results in fewer surface active sites to which CeO2 can be exposed. From the peaking adjustment of the reduction peaks of the three CuCe catalysts (Table 2), it can be seen that at a Cu/Ce value of 1, the area of the reduction peaks occupies the highest proportion at low temperature, confirming the interaction between CuO and CeO2, and the proportion of CuO-CeO2 interface formed is relatively high. Furthermore, 3Cu1Ce corresponds to the largest high-temperature reduction peak area, confirming the large isolated CuO species inside the catalyst. The H2 consumption of each catalyst at 100–400 ℃ was compared (Table 2), and the theoretical hydrogen consumption of CuO completely reduced in each catalyst was calculated according to the results of ICP-AES, as follows: Compared with 1Cu3Ce (1.68), 1Cu1Ce (3.97) and 1Cu1Ce (7.30), it was found that the theoretical hydrogen consumption of the three catalysts was greater than the actual hydrogen consumption, indicating that the CuO in the three catalysts was not completely reduced. Fig. 5(a) shows the Ce3d peak fitting curve of CuCe samples with different atomic ratios. By peaking according to the assignment of Ce3d spectral peaks defined in the figure, 10 independent peaks can be obtained. The multiple peaks of the Ce3d spectrum correspond to spin-orbit 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 splitting. Among them, u1, u2, u3 and v1, v2, v3 correspond to the orbital splitting of 3d5/2 and 3d3/2, respectively, and the spin-orbital splitting is about Δ=18.6 eV, which is the initial state characteristic peak of tetravalent Ce4f0 [20]. The highest binding energy peaks u1 and v1 are located at 916.9±0.1 eV and 898.3±0.1 eV, respectively, which belong to the state of Ce 3d94 f0 O 2p6. The low binding energy states u2, v2, u3 and v3 at 901.3±0.1 eV, 882.7±0.1 eV, 907.3±0.1 eV and 888.5±0.1 eV, respectively belong to the states of Ce 3d94 f2 O 2p4 and Ce 3d94 f1 O 2p5 [26,27]. u, u0, v and v0 correspond to the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 spin-orbit splitting of Ce(Ⅲ) oxides, and the spin-orbital splitting is about Δ=18.2 eV. The highest binding energy peaks u and v are located at 903.4±0.1 eV and 885.2±0.1 eV, respectively, which belong to Ce 3d94 f1 O 2p6 state. The lowest binding energies u0 and v0 are 899.1±0.1 eV and 880.9±0.1 eV, respectively, which are mainly attributed to the Ce 3d94 f2 O 2p5 state [28]. According to the proportion of Ce(Ⅲ) in Table 3 (Ce3+/(Ce4++Ce3+)), the main chemical valence of the Ce species on the surface of the CuCe oxide catalyst is +4, that is, the CeO2 species is one of major cerium oxides on the surface of CuCe oxide catalyst [29]. Part of CeO2 is reduced by H2 to inexpensive Ce(Ⅲ) species and coexists on the catalyst surface, while the reduction of Ce(Ⅳ) to Ce(Ⅲ) is accompanied by the formation of oxygen vacancies [30]. At the same time, when comparing the dopant atom ratio, it can be seen that with the increase of the introduced Cu species, the proportion of Ce(Ⅲ) species decreases, which may be due to Ce4++Cu*↔Ce3++Cu2+ [57]. When more Cu2+ species are present in the catalyst, the reaction is reversed and the content of Ce(Ⅲ) species is reduced. Fig. 5(b) shows the Cu2p subpeak fitting curve of CuCe samples with different atomic ratios. Six independent peaks can be obtained through subpeaks according to the affiliation of Cu2p spectral peaks defined in the figure. The Cu2p3/2 splitting peak is composed of 933.1±0.1 eV and 934.8±0.1 eV, corresponding to Cu* (Cu0/Cu+) species and Cu2+, respectively. The region between 937 and 948 eV is an oscillating peak, and the presence of a high binding energy and a large oscillating peak is an important indicator of the presence of Cu2+, while Cu* species have a low binding energy and no oscillating peak [31,32]. The presence of Cu2+ is consistent with the characterization of H2-TPR. The distance from the Cu 2p3/2 splitting peak Δ=19.8 eV is the Cu 2p1/2 splitting peak. The proportion of Cu* (Cu*/(Cu*+Cu2+)) is calculated in Table 3. The majority of Cu2+ is reduced to reduced Cu* species, with 3Cu1Ce having the lowest proportion of reduced Cu* species, which is also consistent with the above analysis of the decline in the proportion of Ce(Ⅲ) species. Fig. 5(c) shows the fitting curve of O1s subpeaks of CuCe samples with different atomic ratios. It can be seen that the XPS curve of O1s can be divided into three peaks, the peak at 529.2±0.1 eV is mainly attributed to lattice oxygen (OI). The peak at 530.9±0.1 eV is attributed to oxygen vacancy (OII). The peak at 532.5±0.1 eV is attributed to chemisorbed oxygen species (OⅢ), adsorbed water, or OH- [33,34]. Compared to 1Cu3Ce, the OⅠ of catalysts 1Cu1Ce and 3Cu1Ce moves toward higher binding energy, which is caused by changes in the chemical environment around the lattice oxygen [35]. The calculation results of oxygen vacancy content (OⅡ) are shown in Table 3. OⅡ/(OⅠ+OⅡ+OⅢ) represents the proportion of oxygen vacancies. As the Cu proportion decreases, the OⅡ content first increases and then decreases, with 1Cu1Ce having the highest OⅡ proportion. Combined with XRD characterization, it can be concluded that more Cu-O-Ce solution interfaces and oxygen vacancies are formed on the surface of 1Cu1Ce catalyst, which is consistent with the results of H2-TPR, which also makes Cu species more easily reduced to form catalytic active sites. In the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, the oxygen vacancy combines with the CO adsorbed and activated on the surface, which also promotes the stability of the reaction intermediates [36]. The results of XPS analysis showed that when comparing CuCe oxide catalysts, there were more oxygen vacancies and low metal active sites on the surface of 1Cu1Ce, which contributed to the high activity of the catalyst in the RWGS. Fig. 6 shows the change of oxygen vacancies on the surface of composite oxides using Raman spectroscopy. In CeO2, a characteristic peak of fluorite structure around 463 cm−1 was observed, which is attributed to the symmetric F2 g symmetric stretching vibration of the octacoordinate Ce-O bond [37]. The intensity of F2 g peaks in the three CuCe catalysts is weakened, and at the same time, it moves towards the low Raman shift, which is due to the lattice structure change and lattice expansion and mode softening caused by the intermediate doping of CuO and CeO2, resulting in oxygen vacancies. Lattice expansion and mode softening occur when oxygen vacancies are produced [38], each of which is produced by two ­Ce3+ ions (ionic radius 1.143 Å) replacing two ­Ce4+ ions (0.970 Å), which is well confirmed by XRD characterization results. Furthermore, a broad Raman scattering peak was observed near 600 cm−1, which is due to a D-lattice defect caused by an oxygen defect [39]. Combined with XPS characterization analysis, Cu doping leads to a certain amount of Ce(Ⅳ)→Ce(Ⅲ) conversion, and more oxygen vacancies are generated [40], and the Raman shift difference between the D-peak (600 cm−1) and the F2 g peak (463 cm−1) is about 140 cm−1. It shows that the oxygen vacancy of CuCe catalyst is generated by the intrinsic defect (Ce(Ⅳ)→Ce(Ⅲ)) [41]. The IF2g/ID values of the three CuCe catalysts were calculated, and their relative peak area ratio could reveal the concentration of oxygen vacancies in CuCe catalysts [40]. The calculated results show that the IF2g/ID values of the 1Cu3Ce, 1Cu1Ce and 3Cu1Ce catalysts [42,43] are 3.99, 5.06 and 3.06 respectively. The highest IF2g/ID values of 1Cu1Ce catalysts indicate that more oxygen vacancies are created in the H2 reduction process [44]. The catalyst was characterized by CO2-TPD to study the distribution of surface alkaline sites ( Fig. 7). The peaks are divided into three regions according to alkaline intensity ( Table 4): weakly alkaline region below 150 ℃ (α), moderately alkaline region between 150 ℃ and 400 ℃ (β1 and β2), and strongly alkaline region above 450 ℃ (γ1 and γ2) [45]. Among them, the multiple desorption peaks observed in the medium-alkaline region and the strongly alkaline region are related to the different adsorption states of CO2 on the catalyst surface [46], which may be caused by the formation of different types of carbonates on the catalyst surface [47], which is consistent with the observation in situ infrared. By comparison, it was found that the adsorption capacity of CO2 by CeO2 was less, and the adsorption capacity of CO2 was increased by more than 5 times after Cu doping, which was mainly attributed to the interaction between Cu and Ce [48] and the correlation between the formed Cu-O-Ce interface structure. The addition of Cu is more conducive to the formation of basic site on the catalyst surface and the adsorption of CO2. With the increase of Cu content in the catalyst, the CO2 desorption peak shifted slightly to high temperature, indicating that the catalyst's adsorption capacity for CO2 was enhanced, but too strong adsorption capacity for CO2 may occupy too many active sites, which is not conducive to the reaction. Guo et al. [49] have shown that intermediate substances adsorbed at strong alkaline sites are more inclined to over-hydrogenate into methanol rather than dissociated to CO. In contrast, CO2 adsorbed at 180–350 ℃ is more conducive to the formation of HCO2 - species, and HCO2 - species is an important intermediate for the catalytic production of CO [50]. Therefore, the presence of moderately basic sites is more conducive to the activation and reduction of CO2, and too weak or too strong adsorption is not conducive to the catalytic reaction. Comparing the three CuCe catalysts, the medium alkaline site of 1Cu1Ce is the highest. In addition, the total amount of CO2 desorption by 1Cu1Ce is also the largest, which may be related to the high specific surface area of 1Cu1Ce combined with the characterization results of N2-adsorption desorption. The efficiency of interfacial electron transfer of the catalyst surface was also demonstrated by electrochemical and photoluminescence (PL) characterization ( Fig. 8). Fig. 8(a) shows that the four catalysts all have obvious fluorescence signals at about 400 nm, while the nanocrystals emit light in the range of 350 nm to 550 nm due to a large number of surface defects [51], so there are a large number of the oxygen defects in the catalysts. In addition, CeO2 has the strongest fluorescence signal, indicating that electrons generated by CeO2 after photoexcitation recombine faster, which is unfavorable for the process of photothermal catalysis. When Cu/Ce=1, the fluorescence intensity is the lowest, indicating that recombination rate of the photo-induced electrons and holes is the highest, and the hot electrons stimulates by the LSPR effect of Cu can be effectively separated and transferred, which is the main factor for the good photocatalytic performance of CuCe [52,53]. Fig. 8(b) shows the Nyquist curves of CuCe and CeO2 and the corresponding impedance values. Compared with the shape of the catalyst in the high frequency region, the impedance of CeO2 is the largest, indicating that the CeO2 sample has the largest impedance and the most difficult electron transfer. With the addition of Cu, the impedance of the catalyst was reduced to varying degrees, which, combined with the characterization of H2-TPR, may be due to the fact that the low-cost metal exposed on the surface after oxygen reduction improves the efficiency of surface electron transfer, and the minimum impedance of the 1Cu1Ce sample also confirms that it is easier to form oxygen vacancies on the surface of 1Cu1Ce. Fig. 8(c) shows the diffuse reflectance spectra of UV–vis after reduction of CuCe and CeO2. It can be seen from the figure that pure CeO2 mainly absorbs photons in the ultraviolet range below 400 nm. When Cu is incorporated, the catalyst has broader light absorption, especially at 400 nm to 800 nm. In particular, 1Cu1Ce and 1Cu3Ce indicate that Cu species on the catalyst surface can significantly improve the photo adsorption of the catalyst [54]. The diffuse reflection absorption spectrum of the CuCe-doped catalyst consists of two peaks between 370 and 420 nm and 570–620 nm caused by the LSPR effect of Cu, indicating that visible light (420–780 nm) stimulate the plasma effect can be made of Cu [17]. In addition, Compared with 3Cu1Ce the peaks of 1Cu1Ce and 3Cu1Ce were found to have a significant red shift and the peaks of 1Cu3Ce were found to have a significant blue shift. This is because the location and width of the LSPR band depends on the density of free electrons in Cu and the red shift of the peak is mainly due to the Cu concentration, while the smaller and more compact nanostructure causes the blue shift of the peak [55]. At the same time, it is assumed that a broader absorption band also indicates a larger particle size [56]. It can be seen from the figure that 1Cu1Ce has the broadest absorption band, indicating that Cu1Ce1 has the largest CuO particle size and is consistent with XRD. Fig. 8(d) calculates the band gap widths of the three, and the band gap widths of 1Cu3Ce, 1Cu1Ce and 3Cu1Ce are 0.89 eV, 0.65 eV and 0.93 eV, respectively, which is much narrower than the band gap widths of CeO2 (2.79 eV). The absorption red shift and narrower band gap of CuCe catalysts suggest that the introduction of Cu doping into CeO2 can actually improve the light trapping capacity and regulate the energy gap of the catalyst [57]. Comparing the band gap widths of CuCe shows that the catalyst has the best light absorption performance when Cu/Ce=1, and the band gap can be adjusted to be narrower, and the narrow band gap width means that the energy required for electron transition is lower. The smaller the bond to the conduction band, the more conducive to electron migration, which is also a key factor for the efficient photocatalytic performance of the catalyst. The photoelectric results show that under the experimental conditions, the Cu doping amount of Cu/Ce=1 is the best value for constructing the photosensitive catalyst and can stimulate the LSPR effect of Cu. In addition, the heat distribution on the catalyst surface was verified by thermal imager (Fig. S7). After 10 s of irradiation with 300 W all-band xenon lamp light source, it was found that the catalysts all heated up after illumination, which was in sharp contrast to cerium oxide. The temperature from high to low is 1Cu1Ce>1Cu3Ce>3Cu1Ce>CeO2, which may be caused by electrons radiating energy in the form of heat, which proves the generation of LSPR effect [58]. To gain a deeper understanding of the RWGS responses to 1Cu1Ce, an in situ DRIFTS study was performed, as shown in Fig. 9. When the reaction gas is introduced into the sample tank and there is no light, two pairs of acromion peaks can be found at 3576–3761 cm−1, which is mainly due to the O-H vibration in the product H2O [59] and the vibration mode of Cen+-OH [60], in which the vibration of Cen+-OH is the main factor. The range from 2200 to 2400 cm−1 is attributed to the stretching mode of CO, which is due to the adsorption of CO2. At 2168 cm−1, 2144 cm−1 and 2076 cm−1, the adsorbed CO, physically adsorbed CO, linear adsorption and isolated CO bridge are attributed to Cen+, respectively [61]. Furthermore, the obvious stretching vibration peaks at 1220–1550 cm−1 are attributed to various carbonates and bicarbonates [50]. The emergence of more carbonate species is consistent with the results of CO2-TPD. It was observed that the intensity of the O-H peak decreased with increasing temperature, indicating that higher temperatures facilitate the dissociation of H2O and Cen+-OH. Conversely, the intensity of the CO peak increased with temperature, and was higher under light conditions, suggesting that both temperature and light promote the catalytic reaction, resulting in the production of more CO. The appearance of carbonate and bicarbonate peaks represents the appearance of intermediate carbonate or bicarbonate species during the course of the reaction. In addition, O-C-O stretching peaks are also found under light conditions, which are related to formate formation [17,50,62]. Therefore, the reaction path of the catalyst is inconsistent under the no-light and light-free conditions. Fig. 10(a-c) shows the catalytic activity and activation energy of CuCe catalysts of different proportions in RWGS, and the catalytic activity of the catalyst is compared with the equilibrium yield [56]. Among them, CeO2 can catalyze the conversion of CO2 at 350℃, while the Cu-doped catalyst has a certain catalytic activity at 200℃, and at the reaction temperature of 200–450℃, the yield of CO increases gradually and the CO selectivity of all catalysts is 100 %. Furthermore, the CO yield of the Cu-Ce catalysts from high to low was 1Cu1Ce>1Cu3Ce>3Cu1Ce. Among these, 1Cu1Ce exhibited near-equilibrium yield, achieving a CO yield of 31.9 % at 350℃, surpassing the catalytic efficiency of the photothermal materials reported by Zhang and Bo et al. [63,64] under lower space velocities. This is consistent with the temperature rise trend of the catalyst in thermal imaging, further indicating that heat generated by carrier complexation in the illumination process and the LSPR effect of copper nanoparticles plays an important role in the photothermal catalysis process. And the apparent activation energies were 33.84 kJ/mol, 35.58 kJ/mol and 42.95 kJ/mol, respectively. When the optimal Cu/Ce=1 is chosen for thermal catalysis, it is found that the CO yield is more than 15 % lower than that under light conditions and the activation energy is 66.88 kJ/mol, which is much higher than the apparent activation energy under light conditions. This indicates that the reaction course is not completely consistent under light and non-light conditions, and also confirms that the reaction intermediates are different under light and non-light conditions. As shown in Fig. 10(d), comparing the photothermal yield of CO of the three catalysts at 450℃ with the oxygen vacancy concentration IF2g/ID value of Raman test, it was found that the maximum IF2g/ID value was obtained when Cu/Ce=1, and the IF2g/ID value also showed a linear relationship with the trend of CO yield of the three CuCe catalysts. Furthermore, additional catalysts, 1Cu2Ce and 2Cu1Ce, were prepared (Fig. S8) and were also found to follow this linear relationship. These results indicate that higher oxygen vacancy is an important factor affecting the photothermal conversion activity of CO2. The stability and reusability of the catalyst were tested ( Fig. 11), and it was found that after 72 h of photothermal catalysis, the CO yield of 1Cu1Ce slowly decreased to about 36 %, but the selectivity of CO remained at 100 %. After repeated use for 10 times, the photothermal catalytic performance of 1Cu1Ce at 450 ℃ did not decrease significantly, showing that the prepared CuCe catalyst has excellent stability. After the completion of the life test for the 1Cu1Ce catalyst, the crystalline structure of the catalyst were characterized, and the XRD spectra of the catalyst after reaction were compared with those of the freshly reduced catalyst ( Fig. 12). The characteristic peaks of cerianite CeO2 (PDF#43–1002) and Cu (PDF#04–0836) were both found, and it was found that the diffraction peaks after the use of catalysts were sharper. According to Sherrer formula, the grain size of Cu (111) crystal surface of fresh catalyst after reduction is 17.12 nm. After life test, the grain size grows to more than double to 38.77 nm of Cu particle size. The catalyst was subjected to TEM characterization after lifespan testing (Fig. S9), revealing an average Cu particle size of 37.8±0.2 nm, compared to an average Cu particle size of 16.7±0.2 nm in the freshly reduced catalyst. This finding is consistent with the results obtained from XRD characterization. Therefore, the decrease of catalytic active site density caused by the growth of nanoparticles is the main factor limiting the life of 1Cu1Ce catalyst. There are two widely accepted mechanisms for RWGS: the REDOX mechanism and the intermediate species decomposition mechanism [65]. Combined with the DRIFTS characterization, it is speculated that 1Cu1Ce mainly follows the decomposition mechanism of the intermediate species, and the intermediate products are mainly carbonate under light conditions and carbonate and formate under light conditions. Therefore, a possible catalytic cycle diagram is proposed, as shown in Fig. 13 After reduction of the catalyst, oxygen vacancies and active sites with low metal content are formed. There are seven reaction steps in the light process: (I) hydrogen is dissociated at the Cu site and the dissociated H is filled into the oxygen vacancies through hydrogen overflow [17]; (Ⅱ) CO2 reacted with reactive oxygen species to produce intermediate CO3 2- species; (Ⅲ) migration of H species leading to HCO3 - intermediate species; (Ⅳ) migration and electrophilic addition of H species leading to HCOO intermediate species; (Ⅴ) Reactive oxygen species fill oxygen vacancies [61]; (Ⅵ) The intermediate species releases CO(g) and simultaneously forms Ce4+-OH; (Ⅶ) -OH reacts with H species to form H2O and forms new oxygen vacancies. Under dark conditions, reduced electron migration makes HCO3 - intermediate species more prone to decompose directly into CO via electrophilic addition to the surface of Cu0 [66]. However, under light conditions, HCO3 - species are converted back to Cen+-OH structures, which then decompose into CO. This is consistent with the observation in Fig. 9(c), where the O-H peak intensity is greater under light conditions. 4 Conclusion In this paper, the CuCe bimetal doped catalyst was prepared by sol-gel method, and the existence of Cu-O-Ce interface on the catalyst surface was proved. In thermal catalysis, the highly enriched Cu active sites and oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface provide sufficient reaction sites for RWGS. After illumination, the narrow band gap and fast electron migration can effectively prevent the recombination of electron holes and stimulate the LSPR effect of Cu. Not only that, CuCe also produces additional intermediate substances such as formates under light, speeding up the reaction speed, thus proposing a reasonable catalytic cycle path, so that the catalyst shows 100 % selectivity and significant catalytic activity to CO under light. Additionally, the CuCe catalyst demonstrated good stability and reusability. However, the aggregation and growth of Cu nanoparticles is the main limiting factor for the catalyst's stability. In addition, the catalysts with different Cu/Ce ratios were prepared and characterized. It was found that the catalyst with Cu/Ce=1 had the most oxygen vacancy, and the yield was consistent with that of CO2. This is mainly due to the fact that when Cu and Ce are mixed at an atomic ratio of 1:1, CeO2 species, which are easy to form smaller particles, are more likely to enter the CuO lattice, form CuxCe1-xO2-y solid solution, and obtain the Cu-O-Ce interface, which promotes the reduction of surface oxygen to form oxygen vacancies and metal active sites. Both PL and UV–vis indicate that the catalyst has the best thermoelectron transfer efficiency when Cu/Ce=1, and the narrow band gap also indicates that the catalyst has good photosensitivity. Therefore, CuCe is a promising photothermal catalyst for RWGS. CRediT authorship contribution statement Changjian Zhou: Visualization, Software, Resources. coredata.dc:description: The photothermal catalytic reverse water gas shift reaction (RWGS) can convert CO2 into other high-value-added chemical resources under mild conditions. However, the design and development of high-performance catalysts is a major challenge. In this work, different proportions of CuCe bimetallic catalysts were synthesized using the sol-gel method and applied to RWGS. Under the visible light heat catalytic condition at 450 ℃, the CO yield can be increased by about 20 % compared to thermal catalysis, which is better than most metal-based catalysts reported in the literature. Moreover, the catalyst exhibited good stability and reusability, with the primary factor affecting the stability of the CuCe catalyst being the growth of Cu nanoparticles. The characterization shows that at Cu/Ce=1, the separation efficiency of electron-hole separation is the highest, and the hot electrons generated by the LSPR effect of Cu can be effectively separated and transferred, producing more oxygen vacancies and suitable alkaline sites, so it has the best photothermal catalytic performance. Furthermore, the catalyst is dominated by the formate pathway under light conditions, and this work provides a new RWGS strategy.
